articles.title: Solano leaders discuss sea level rise
articles.author: Nick McConnell
articles.summary: The Solano Bayshore Resiliency Project will plan for 6.5 feet of sea level rise plus ten feet of storm surge before the year 2100. The project will be funded on the state level and administered by Solano County, its coastal cities and the Fairfield-Suisun Sewer District. The data collected will be crafted into an action plan.

articles.title: Australia hit by worst hay fever season in years, as experts reveal the causes and how to prevent it
articles.author: Jennifer Shahin
articles.summary: This year's Australian spring has unleashed a severe wave of hay fever. It's one of the worst seasons yet due to weather extremes and record-breaking heat. Melbourne, Canberra, Sydney, Hobart, and Brisbane are the worst-hit cities. Reducing exposure to pollen is beneficial during this season to help ease symptoms.

articles.title: Bone fossil not evidence Australia's ancient megafauna was killed by humans: study
articles.author: Peter de Kruijff
articles.summary: People arrived at Sahul 65,000 years ago. Megafauna in Australia died out about 40,000 ago. Scientists believe climate change and hunting killed the megafauna. A tibia of a giant kangaroo with cut marks made by humans was found in a West Australian cave 57 years ago, but a new study suggests it was struck by Aboriginal people.

articles.title: Australia news live: extreme weather warnings as Sydney forecast to hit hottest ever October day; US company bids to buy Rex
articles.author: Nick Visser
articles.summary: Bureau of Meteorology expects hot, dry and windy weather across large parts of New South Wales today. If temperatures in Sydney's CBD reach 39C, the city's October heat record of 38.2C, set in 2004 at Observatory Hill, could fall. On Tuesday, both Queensland and NSW recorded their highest ever October temperatures.

articles.title: Australia news live: Sydney forecast to have hottest ever October day as Melbourne braces for ...
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Predicted high of 39C would be hotter than 38.2C October record from 2004. Follow today's news live on CNN iReport.com.  iReport is a news service that provides live updates on events in the UK and provides information on developments in the news.

articles.title: Climate Action Plan update, open house Wednesday
articles.author: Steamboat Pilot
articles.summary: The Routt County Climate Action Plan Collaborative will host a public open house and plan update from 5:30-7:30 p.m. Wednesday at Library Hall in Steamboat Springs. Attendees can learn about what local governments and partners are doing to fight climate change.

articles.title: Sydney hit with 40C temperatures and winds
articles.author: Alexandra Feiam
articles.summary: Millions of Australians are bracing for another day of record-breaking temperatures as a heatwave sweeps the country's northeast. A heatwave warning has been issued for residents in The Gulf Country, Northern Goldfields and Upper Flinders, North West, Channel Country and Maranoa and Warrego Districts. It will be 39C in Sydney on Wednesday, with a chance of thunderstorms in the state capital from Wednesday afternoon. The extreme conditions have sparked fire warnings or bans in several states.

articles.title: Weather: Wild storms hit one state while Aussies sweat through record-breaking heat
articles.author: Alexandra Feiam
articles.summary: Millions of Australians are bracing for another day of record-breaking temperatures on Wednesday. A heatwave warning has been issued for residents in The Gulf Country, Northern Goldfields and Upper Flinders, North West, Channel Country and Maranoa and Warrego Districts. It will be hot and windy across NSW on Wednesday, with a maximum of 39C predicted for Sydney. The Bureau of Meteorology has issued a fire weather warning for the Greater Hunter, Greater Sydney Region, Illawarra/Shoalhaven and Upper Central West Plains fire districts.

articles.title: Study offers glimpse of severe climate change anxiety in Canada
articles.author: Canadian Press
articles.summary: David Toro attended a climate change anxiety peer-support group at Concordia University in late 2023. The group helped him deal with his feelings of dread and powerlessness when he thought about climate change. A national survey estimates about 2.3% of people over 13 in Canada experience climate change anxiousness.

articles.title: Unprecedented weather warning as 'significant records set' across Australia
articles.author: Joe Attanasio
articles.summary: Queensland and New South Wales recorded their hottest October day on record on Tuesday. A heatwave warning has been issued for residents in Northern and central Queensland, Central Western Australia and the Upper Flinders in South Australia. There is a fire ban in place in NSW, gale force winds are forecast to batter Victoria.

articles.title: Warning as Aussie town hits 46.1 degrees as heat records broken: 'Incredibly hot'
articles.author: Joe Attanasio
articles.summary: Queensland and New South Wales recorded their hottest October day on record on Tuesday. A heatwave warning has been issued for residents in Northern and central Queensland, Central Western Australia and the Upper Flinders in South Australia. There is a fire ban in place in NSW, gale force winds are forecast to batter Victoria.

articles.title: Increasing heat is super-charging Arctic climate and weather extremes
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: By evaluating historical climate records, observational and projection data, an international team of researchers found a "pushing and pushing" of the climate system, according to the researchers.    .   in their report.  In it, they found that the climate is getting warmer.

articles.title: One of most vulnerable states to climate change lacks ‘political will' to mitigate its disaster threats
articles.author: The Clarksdale Press Register
articles.summary: This is the last of three stories in a series on climate vulnerability and resilience in Mississippi. Click here for the first and second stories. The 20th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina was on the eve of the conference room meeting of the Mississippi Building Code Council where members of the council were confused.

articles.title: Farmers issue warning as staple crops become increasingly difficult to grow: 'We lost nearly 40%'
articles.author: Christine Dulion
articles.summary: Farmers across Turkey are warning that extreme weather events are pushing their crops and livelihoods to the brink. A series of devastating frosts, hailstorms, and record-breaking heatwaves has wiped out major portions of the country's citrus, apricot, and hazelnut harvests. Lemon prices in Turkey have surged to 3 euros per kilo ($1.60 per pound) as supplies shrink.

articles.title: Swept away homes, unearthed graves, submerged hunting trails: how Typhoon Halong destroyed an Alaskan village
articles.author: Jenni Monet
articles.summary: Typhoon Halong pummeled as many as 15 villages across the Yukon-Kuskokwim (YK) delta, an expanse the size of Oregon. The disaster underscored the growing dangers in the YK delta: thawing permafrost, chronic erosion and increased flooding from storms that are becoming stronger and more frequent. The region is one of six major climate impact zones in Alaska.

articles.title: Record heat, 130km/h winds sweep Australia
articles.author: Alexandra Feiam
articles.summary: A total fire ban has been declared across large parts of Australia's east coast as intense temperatures smash millions of Australians. A heatwave warning has been issued for residents in The Gulf Country, Northern Goldfields and Upper Flinders, North West, Channel Country and Maranoa and Warrego Districts. On Wednesday, Sydney will be scorching hot and windy with a maximum of 39C. It will be very windy and cloudy in Melbourne on Wednesday, with a high chance of rain and a thunderstorm.

articles.title: Three states hit record temps as Aus swelters in heatwave
articles.summary: Birdsville in Queensland hit 46.1degC yesterday, the hottest October day in the state's history. Sydney is forecast to swelter through an expected top of 38C on Wednesday. A total fire ban has been declared for the regions of Greater Sydney, Greater Hunter, Illawarra/Shoalhaven, Upper Central West Plains and North Western. Melbourne and Victoria are bracing for destructive winds and thunderstorm asthma conditions.

articles.title: Experts call for climate-resilient construction
articles.author: Our Correspondent
articles.summary: Experts call for climate-resilient construction in Pakistan to mitigate the growing impact of climate change on public health. They recommend shaded roofs, air vents, and solar-reflective paints as practical, low-cost solutions. Rising temperatures have been linked to stunted growth in newborns and higher rates of depression and mental illness in regions where climate effects are more pronounced.

articles.title: Australia could have better than expected wheat yields this year
articles.author: Doug Falconer
articles.summary: Analysts have raised their estimates for Australia's wheat harvest by half a million tonnes since late last month. The median of their estimates was for Australia to produce 35.7 million tonnes of wheat, which would be the third-biggest harvest on record. Australia is one of the world's biggest exporters of wheat as well as barley and canola.

articles.title: Sydney weather LIVE: Extreme fire danger, dangerous winds, heat records expected to fall
articles.author: Angus Dalton
articles.summary: Today could be the hottest October day on record in Sydney. The current record for this month is 19.7 degrees. The Bureau of Meteorology expects the temperature to spike by 20 degrees to reach 39 degrees by 2 pm. There are high winds, extreme fire danger, risk of thunderstorm and severe heatwave warning for parts of NSW.

articles.title: IMD Issues Heavy Rainfall Warning for Tamil Nadu Coastal Districts
articles.author: Naveen
articles.summary: Fishermen are advised not to venture into the sea from 21st to 25th. A low pressure area has formed over the southwest Bay of Bengal and is expected to intensify into a depression tomorrow afternoon. The RMC has issued orange alert for seven coastal and delta districts, including Ramanathapuram, Cuddalore and Thanjavur and Puducherry.

articles.title: Canadian companies last among G7 on climate transition planning: Report
articles.author: Catherine Mcintyre
articles.summary: Only 5% of Canadian companies have credible climate transition plans, according to a new report from Business Future Pathways. That puts Canada last among the G7 countries and Australia, behind the U.S., where 6% of firms have credible plans. Japanese firms were the most advanced in G7, with 23% of companies having solid transition plans.

articles.title: Millions impacted by wild weather
articles.author: Alexandra Feiam
articles.summary: Destructive winds have torn through parts of Australia, while other areas have endured record-breaking heat. On Tuesday night, millions of people were warned to power their mobile devices before destructive winds blast through Victoria. The Bureau of Meteorology warned 130km/h wind gusts would hit the west coast of CapCape Otway on Wednesday. Geelong, the Mornington Peninsula and south Gippsland will be hit with damaging gusts up to 120 km/h on Wednesday afternoon. 100km/H gusts will sweep through Melbourne. A total fire ban has been declared across large parts of the east coast.

articles.title: Millions impacted as wild weather hits one state, while others sweat through record-breaking heat
articles.author: Alexandra Feiam
articles.summary: Destructive winds have torn through parts of Australia, while other areas have endured record-breaking heat. On Tuesday night, millions of people were warned to power their mobile devices before destructive winds blast through Victoria. The Bureau of Meteorology warned 130km/h wind gusts would hit the west coast of CapCape Otway on Wednesday. Geelong, the Mornington Peninsula and south Gippsland will be hit with damaging gusts up to 120 km/h on Wednesday afternoon. 100km/H gusts will sweep through Melbourne. A total fire ban has been declared across large parts of the east coast.

articles.title: La Niña's fingerprints are all over winter weather forecasts
articles.author: Doyle Rice
articles.summary: After a short absence, climate troublemaker La Niña is back and forecasters say it could have a big impact on the winter weather outlook. The cycle swings between warmer and cooler seawater in a region along the equator in the tropical Pacific Ocean. It usually only comes every few years, but it made an appearance in winter 2024-2025 for several months as well. It's not dangerous, but its association with a more active Atlantic hurricane season, an increased threat of wildfires in some regions, and the chances for disastrous floods or other extreme weather.

articles.title: Birdsville breaks October records as severe heatwave blankets parts of Queensland
articles.author: Johanna Marie
articles.summary: Bureau of Meteorology is warning of extreme heatwave conditions spreading across a larger part of Queensland. Mount Isa, the northern Goldfields and Charters Towers will be hit with temperatures in the 40s for the next three days. The outback town of Birdsville saw the mercury skyrocket to 46 degrees Celsius on Tuesday afternoon, making it Queensland's hottest October day on record.

articles.title: UN climate chief calls for stepping up climate action & finance ahead of COP30
articles.summary: UN Climate Change chief Simon Stiell has urged countries to deliver a rapid surge in climate finance ahead of COP30. He warned that developing nations remain short of the resources needed to withstand worsening storms, floods and droughts. 67 developing countries have submitted adaptation plans, including 23 from least developed countries and 14 small island developing States.

articles.title: Flood risk already raining on Australian home prices
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: The east coast and tropics have always been prone to flooding but climate change has been fuelling increasingly heavy downpours. The warmer atmosphere is capable of holding more moisture and energy to fuel storms, which is a result of climate change, according to scientists.

articles.title: Million buck benchmark loses sparkle in house value run
articles.author: Ben Mckay
articles.summary: Darwin has the highest house price growth of 12.9 per cent over the last year. Nightcliff is the closest suburb to the million-dollar mark with a median house value of $944,871. Tasmania has four seven-figure suburbs and none.

articles.title: Million buck benchmark loses sparkle in house value run
articles.author: Ben McKay
articles.summary: Million-dollar homes are increasingly commonplace in Australia. One in every three suburbs in Australia has a median seven-figure price tag, according to a new research. The research shows roughly one in three suburbs pack a median 7.5-8 million dollar price tag.

articles.title: The stumbling block to our energy ambitions
articles.author: Tony Wood
articles.summary: The challenges of delivering Australia's energy transition have never been clearer. The core challenge of the energy transition is to decouple energy use from emissions. The next few years may determine how well or how poorly we connect them. For many decades, there has been a globally consistent positive relationship between per capita energy use and GDP, but Australia has partly decoupled that relationship.

articles.title: Protecting our climate-induced displaced population
articles.author: Syeda Shaimila Nahin
articles.summary: Bangladesh is one of the most vulnerable countries to climate change. Every year, families from coastal districts flee their homes because of rising tides, eroding riverbanks, and cyclones. They are climate-induced internally displaced people, and in Bangladesh, they remain largely invisible to the law. According to the International Organization for Migration, nearly 13.3 million people could be displaced within Bangladesh by 2050 due to climate-related impacts. There is no specific legal or policy framework that recognises them or protects their rights.

articles.title: Landscape of anticipatory action for health in a changing climate
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Climate change is increasing the frequency of extreme weather events, food insecurity, and disease outbreaks. There are growing economic and social problems due to the effects of climate change, according to the World Economic Forum (WEF). The WEF reports that there is a growing economic crisis due to climate change.

articles.title: Ottawa's new plan details top climate risks and how to address them
articles.author: Natasha O'Neill
articles.summary: Environment and Climate Change Committee approved a five-year plan to prepare Ottawa for climate change. The plan includes a $25 million budget for flood and infrastructure resilience, cooling amenities, extreme weather preparness and environmental protection. A further $149.5 million will be used from rate taxes to upgrade water infrastructure and build flood resilience.

articles.title: What is methane and what's its role in climate change?
articles.author: Deutsche Welle
articles.summary: Methane traps 84 times as much heat as CO2. It's responsible for 20-30% of CO2 emissions since the Industrial Revolution. 60% of the methane that makes it into the atmosphere comes from human activities. The European Union passed a regulation last year forcing fossil fuel companies to measure, report and reduce how much methane they are emitting.

articles.title: La Niña is officially here: What you need to know for the winter months ahead
articles.author: Keagan Ostop
articles.summary: There is an increased risk of wildfires and severe storms due to La Niña. Global temperatures are rising due to human-caused climate change. The last few years have been warmer than what El Niño temperatures were a decade ago. The Pacific Ocean is warming due to the rise in greenhouse gases emitted by humans.

articles.title: La Niña is officially here: What you need to know for the winter months ahead
articles.author: Keagan Ostop
articles.summary: There is an increased risk of wildfires and severe storms due to La Niña. La Niñas are part of a natural climate cycle known as the El Niño - Southern Oscillation (ENSO). The last few years of El Niño have been warmer than what El Niño temperatures were a decade ago. This is because of the rise in greenhouse gases emitted by human activity.

articles.title: Oh, the HORROR! Climate Change to Make More Rain in the Sahara Desert
articles.author: Anthony Watts
articles.summary: By the second half of the 21st century, the Sahara Desert could see 75% more precipitation than its historical norm. Under extreme climate conditions, rainfall is expected to increase in southeastern and south-central Africa. The southwestern region will be drier, with an anticipated 5% decline in precipitation.

articles.title: HEADLINE: 'When Climate Science Gets Ignored, Weather Porn Drives Headlines And Policy', by Bjorn Lomborg
articles.author: Bjorn Lomborg
articles.summary: When Climate Science Gets Ignored, Weather Porn Drives Headlines and Policy. When it's found to be wrong, it gets huge coverage. 2025 is shaping up as one of the least fiery years on record across most areas of the world. The total burned area in Africa, the Americas, Asia and Europe is down.

articles.title: Sour Melissa: The Hurricane Watch for October 21st
articles.author: Dr. Ryan Truchelut
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Melissa is forecast to strengthen and meander into the weekend. Cuba, Jamaica, Hispaniola, and the Bahamas are at the greatest risk. Melissa is not expected to be a U.S. threat. Almanac: It's T…

articles.title: Spring heatwave spreads as wild winds hit another state
articles.author: Callum Godde
articles.summary: The spring heatwave in Australia has broken temperature records in three states. Millions of people will get a taste of the heatwave.    in the cities. The heatwave is expected to last for the next few days in some states, including Victoria.

articles.title: In the era of ‘degrowth', how long can business schools keep teaching about maximising profits?
articles.author: Carla Liuzzo
articles.summary: Sustainability is a hot topic in Australian business schools. Business students are interested in learning the skills they would need under an alternative post-growth future. Degrowth is starting to be taught explicitly in business schools in Europe and the US. Business schools have been criticised for not doing enough to address climate change.

articles.title: As Florida enjoys taste of fall, Australia sets enormous heat records
articles.author: David Nazario
articles.summary: October heat records have been broken in several states across Australia in recent days. The Queensland Outback town of Birdsville set a record this past Tuesday reaching 46.1 degrees Celsius, which is the first occurrence during the month of October. Some suburbs in Sydney, Australia were forecast to climb into the 40C threshold the rest of the week.

articles.title: Property fetish ducks climate responsibility
articles.author: Dr Sasha Maher
articles.summary: At its core, adaptation to climate change is about survival. Mitigation is the effort to stem the tide, to reduce the damage before it becomes irreversible. New Zealand is a country acutely vulnerable to rising seas, floods, and ecological disruption. Most threatened are Indigenous Māori, people with disabilities, and low-income communities.

articles.title: Expert warns Manchester could become 'unliveable' due to global climate change
articles.author: Christopher Sharp
articles.summary: Expert warns Manchester could become 'unliveable' due to global climate change. In recent years, the UK has experienced wetter winters and drier summers, leading to increased scrutiny of the long-term effects of climate change and the country's preparedness for it. Lindsay Groves, a senior net zero consultant at Consultus Sustainability, warned that even cities further inland could be at risk.

articles.title: ‘Wheel of Fortune': Ryan Seacrest Fires Back After Fans Blast Change He Made to Show
articles.author: Brittany Sims
articles.summary: Some clouds this evening will give way to mainly clear skies overnight. There is a slight chance of a rain shower. High 79F. Winds will be WSW at 5 to 10 mph, with the risk of rain in the evening. Tomorrow's weather will be mostly sunny.

articles.title: What is methane?
articles.summary: Methane traps 84 times as much heat as CO2. It's responsible for 20-30% of global warming since the Industrial Revolution. 60% of the methane that makes it into the atmosphere comes from human activities. The European Union passed a regulation last year forcing fossil fuel companies to measure, report and reduce how much methane they are emitting.

articles.title: Tropical forests at risk of becoming carbon emitters: Study
articles.author: Daily Sabah
articles.summary: Australia's tropical rainforests are emitting more carbon dioxide than they absorb, according to scientists. It's a 'very concernin the world', according to the scientists' report.       in the journal "Climatologist".

articles.title: Miliband Emits More Carbon Dioxide From Flights Than Average Brit Does in 35 Years
articles.author: Guido Fawkes
articles.summary: Ed Miliband emits more carbon dioxide from flights than an average Brit does in 35 years. According to Hot air merchant, Ed Miliband has over the course of a year emitted more CO2 than the average Brit in 35. years. Ed Miliband is the leader of the Labour Party.

articles.title: There was more CO2 in the atmosphere during the dinosaur age: That doesn't help us anyway
articles.author: Christian Urban
articles.summary: There is a dramatic rise in CO2 in the atmosphere. CO2 levels have risen 50 percent in 150 years since the Industrial Revolution. Dinosaurs didn't have to worry about coastal cities, global supply chains, or food production. The Earth was 6-12 degrees warmer, the polar ice caps were largely ice-free, sea levels were higher and tropical conditions prevailed even at high latitudes.

articles.title: HEADLINE: 'Carbon Dioxide Levels Jumped by a Record Amount, U.N. Says', By Raymond Zhong and Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
articles.author: Stephen Heins
articles.summary: Carbon Dioxide Levels Jumped by a Record Amount, U.N. Says. Surging emissions from wildfires may have been behind the increase, which was the largest since modern measurements began more than half a century ago. Last year was Earth's hottest year in recorded history.

articles.title: Tamil Nadu Braces for Monsoon's Wrath: Heavy Rainfall Alerts and Precautions in Place
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Tamil Nadu is bracing itself for the intensified Northeast monsoon. The regional weather office has issued heavy rainfall alerts for several districts. Fishermen have been advised to avoid the sea and relief efforts are being mobilized. A low-pressure system over the Bay of Bengal could develop into a cyclone.

articles.title: Transform your home into a haunted house
articles.author: Kristopher Miller
articles.summary: Hiawatha World is celebrating October. Leaves turn various shades of orange and red, while the weather gets decidedly colder.    .   "Hia wata" means "transformation" in English. "Wata" is the root of "wata".

articles.title: As eastern Australia prepares to swelter, here's how to protect your pets in a heatwave
articles.author: Eelemarni Close-Brown
articles.summary: Temperatures in Sydney are expected to approach 40C on Wednesday. High fire danger is forecast across most of Queensland. RSPCA recommends several ways to keep pets cool in a heatwave, including setting up multiple water bowls, keeping them out of direct sunlight and planning ahead.

articles.title: Scientists propose dimming Sun to curb climate change? New study says it's dangerous
articles.author: The News International
articles.summary: Scientists propose dimming Sun to curb climate change, but new study says it's dangerous. Climate change is wreaking havoc through severe weather patterns, including wildfires, heatwaves, droughts and floods being observed across the globe. It's caused by climate change.

articles.title: Climate Action Plan update, open house Wednesday
articles.author: Steamboat Pilot
articles.summary: The Routt County Climate Action Plan Collaborative will host a public open house and plan update from 5:30-7:30 p.m. Wednesday at Library Hall in Steamboat Springs. The event will feature highlights from the four inaugural CAP Fund recipients and their projects. Child care and Spanish language interpretation will be available.

articles.title: Sea levels are rising faster than in 4,000 years: Hidden threats to cities, causes and impacts
articles.author: TOI Trending Desk
articles.summary: Global sea levels are rising faster than at any point in the last 4,000 years. The Greenland Ice Sheet alone contains enough water to raise global sea levels by 7.4 metres if fully melted. Even small increases in ocean levels amplify the risk of coastal flooding, threatening millions of people in low-lying cities, fertile deltas, and vital economic hubs. Without immediate action, the consequences will escalate dramatically.

articles.title: Scientists issue visible ‘warning signs' after NASA supercomputer predicted when world would end
articles.author: Joshua Nair
articles.summary: A new study from the Toho University in Japan in collaboration with NASA has given us a potential date for the end of the world. According to 400,000 simulations, the year we can expect it all to end is 1,000,002,021. This is because the Sun is expanding and emitting more heat, making the surface of Earth uninhabitable. The oceans will have evaporated and the atmosphere would have thinned ten times.

articles.title: Iceland gets its first mosquitoes, thanks to global warming
articles.author: Newsroom
articles.summary: Iceland is warming at four times the Northern Hemisphere average, making its cold environment more hospitable to species that previously couldn't survive. Global warming has already caused glaciers to melt and brought warmer-water fish, like mackerel, to Icelandic waters. Across Europe, insects once confined to tropical zones are creeping north.

articles.title: Trump's words aren't stopping China, Brazil and many other countries from setting higher climate goals, but progress is slow
articles.author: Shannon Gibson
articles.summary: After 30 years of international climate talks and 10 years of a global treaty, the world is still not on track to stop rising global temperatures. The Trump administration has been pressuring countries to back away from their climate commitments, but many countries are still pressing ahead. China, currently the world's largest greenhouse gas emitter, was lauded for hitting its green energy targets five years early. China's rapid expansion of low-cost renewable energy and electric vehicle manufacturing has reduced pollution in Chinese cities.

articles.title: How will warming permafrost affect climate?
articles.author: Class
articles.summary: Permafrost in Central Alaska has been frozen for millions of years. Global climate change is causing the permafrost to melt for the first time in ages, releasing carbon dioxide into the atmosphere at alarming rates. A group of researchers working out of the Permafrosts Research Tunnel is trying to keep it frozen.

articles.title: Scientists propose dimming Sun to curb climate change? New study says it's dangerous
articles.author: Abu Huraira
articles.summary: Climate change is causing severe weather patterns across the globe. Some scientists propose 'stratospheric aerosol injection' (SAI) to cool the planet and reduce global warming. However, experts warn that SAI is not a viable solution and can cause more harm than good to Earth.

articles.title: Southern Africa Seeks $2.1 Billion to Modernize Agri-Food Systems
articles.author: Ange Jason Quenum
articles.summary: The Southern African Development Community (SADC) and FAO are seeking $2.1 billion in investments to modernize agriculture. The initiative aims to strengthen climate resilience, boost productivity, and enhance food security for 42 million people. SADC outlined four priority investment areas validated during a regional workshop in Harare in September: irrigation, agricultural mechanization, agro-processing and trade facilitation.

articles.title: Health Experts Warn Of Respiratory Risks Amid Worsening Air Quality
articles.author: NDTV
articles.summary: The festive season, seasonal weather changes and increased stubble burning in neighbouring states has exacerbated pollution levels. There are calls for preventive measures to reduce the pollution levels in the state and beyond.   Â      in this case, the state's pollution control authority has called for a preventive measure to reduce pollution.

articles.title: Gov. Ron DeSantis to speak in Martin County at natural area
articles.author: Will Greenlee
articles.summary: Gov. Ron DeSantis and a top Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission official will hold a news conference Nov. 21 at the John C. and Mariana Jones/Hungryland Wildlife and Environmental Area. The natural area is off Southwest Pratt Whitney Road west of Interstate 95 and covers more than 16,600 acres in Martin and Palm Beach counties.

articles.title: Over 900,000 people affected as floods worsen South Sudan crises
articles.author: Sudans Post
articles.summary: Flooding has affected 927,182 people in 26 counties across six states in South Sudan. Nearly 301,000 people have been displaced in 16 counties. UNICEF reports that floods have affected at least 61 schools across Central Equatoria, Jonglei, Upper Nile, Unity, and Western Equatorsia States, impacting 22,000 children and 700 teachers.

articles.title: Your burger's climate impact depends on where you live. Look up your city.
articles.author: The Washington Post
articles.summary: What you eat and where you eat can have a big impact on how much you contribute to climate change, according to a study published Monday. It was based on research published in the journal "Climatology" and published by the University of California, Berkeley.

articles.title: Mosquitoes detected for the first time in Iceland
articles.summary: For the first time in history, mosquitoes have been spotted in Iceland. Until recently, the country was the only place without a mosquito population. Global warming is making Iceland's cold environment more hospitable to species that previously couldn't survive there. The first mosquitoes identified belong to the species Culiseta annulata, known for its resistance to cold.

articles.title: Three major British cities could become 'unliveable' due to climate change
articles.author: newsdesk@nottinghampost.com
articles.summary: In recent years, the UK has experienced increasingly wet winters and dry summers. There are concerns about the long-term effects of climate change and the UK's preparedness for it. Lindsay Groves, a senior consultant at Consultus Sustainability, has proposed that inland cities could be at risk. She warned that whole counties could become unliveable due to climate change.

articles.title: Climate change threatening global grasslands, shrublands; adaptation needed
articles.author: Aryan Rai
articles.summary: Climate change is threatening grasslands, a habitat covering 40 per cent of the planet. Global study examined 74 ecosystems and found that productivity fell by 77 per cent by the fourth year of continuous drought. The findings have implications for India, where recurring droughts threaten ecosystems in Rajasthan, Gujarat and Karnataka.

articles.title: Saving Alexandria from sinking through Japanese technology
articles.author: Abeer Bassiouny Radwan
articles.summary: Alexandria is at risk of flooding and structural collapse due to climate change and sea-level rise. The city's infrastructure is outdated and its buildings are unprotected along the coastal strip. Japan's Johkasou system is a decentralized sanitation management system. It uses a blend of primary, biological, anaerobic, tertiary treatment, and modern membrane technologies.

articles.title: Saving Alexandria from sinking through Japanese technology
articles.summary: Saving Alexandria from sinking through Japanese technology. The city of Alexandria is facing a difficult environmental crisis, threatened by its low-lying coastal location and the advanced age of its infrastructure and vital networks. There are scientific warnings regarding the dangers of climate change and rapidly accelerating sea-level rise.

articles.title: Heat Surge Fuels Arctic Weather Extremes
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: An international team of researchers found a "pushing and triggering" mechanism that has driven the Arctic climate system to a new state. Since 2000, the probability of atmospheric heatwaves has increased by 20%, Atlantic Ocean layer warm events have increased by 76%, sea ice loss events increased by 83%, and Greenland Ice Sheet melt extent increased by 68%.

articles.title: Migratory birds flying high across the sky in search of food and suitable habitats to spend the winter season. These birds travel thousands of kilometers from the cold plains of Siberia to the warmer
articles.summary: Migratory birds are flying high across the sky in search of food and suitable habitats to spend the winter season. They travel thousands of kilometers from the cold plains of Siberia to the warmer regions of South Asia. Their arrival marks the onset of winter in the region.

articles.title: Climate transition plans still critical despite other pressing risks: report
articles.author: Ian Bickis
articles.summary: Report from Business Future Pathways says Canadian businesses must prepare for a range of climate change impacts. It argues that climate transition plans are still crucial to their long-term success in the face of current economic and political challenges.   Â

articles.title: Study: Firms sensitive to rising temperatures deliver lower stock returns
articles.author: Rosemary Anthony
articles.summary: Companies that are more sensitive to climate-driven temperature changes are less profitable, pursue riskier business strategies and generate lower-than-expected returns, according to the study.       .   "Climate change is bad for business".

articles.title: SA actuaries launch free country-specific climate index
articles.author: Hanlie Nordejee
articles.summary: The ASSA Climate Index is free to use. It was developed for the Actuarial Society of South Africa by a multidisciplinary team of actuaries and meteorologists. It measures the frequency of specific extreme weather events against a 30-year base period. The World Meteorological Organisation declared 2024 the hottest year on record.

articles.title: The costs of Trump's campaign to censor climate science
articles.summary: Trump administration cutbacks on climate funding have affected NOAA. Datasets have been removed, federal websites scrubbed and thousands of NOAA staff purged. Dr Frank Marks, 73, is the oldest hurricane hunter still flying for the US government. He has interrupted his retirement to help fill staff shortages across NOAA.

articles.title: Diabetes Drugs Might Counter Brain Decline In Early Alzheimer's Patients
articles.summary: There is a slight chance of a rain shower in the afternoon. The weather will be mostly clear after midnight. The temperature will rise to around 80F with a west wind of 5 to 10 mph. The forecast is partly cloudy.    in addition to the usual low temperatures.

articles.title: EXCLUSIVE: Expert warns three major British cities could become 'unliveable' due to climate change
articles.author: Christopher Sharp
articles.summary: Lindsay Groves has warned that at least three cities in the UK could be at risk from the ravages of climate change. She also warned that entire counties could be under threat from the uninhabitability caused by climate change as well as major cities such as London, Manchester, and York.

articles.title: Tamil Nadu Faces Intense Northeast Monsoon: CM M.K. Stalin Calls for Urgent Measures
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The Northeast monsoon has intensified across Tamil Nadu. Chief Minister M.K. Stalin has issued heavy rainfall alerts for several districts. The regional weather office confirmed that widespread rains have lashed parts of the state. Deputy CM Udhayanidhi Stalin supervised infrastructure works aimed at flood mitigation. Farmers voiced concerns over damaged crops.

articles.title: Tropical forests at risk of becoming carbon emitters: Study
articles.author: Afp
articles.summary: Australia's tropical rainforests are emitting more carbon dioxide than they absorb, according to a new study. It's the first study to show this trend for natural undisturbed forest. The main cause was climate change and its effects on the moisture in the atmosphere and drought.

articles.title: A Storm Leveled Their School. 7 Years Later, They Still Need Help
articles.author: Marcel Honoré
articles.summary: Saipan's Hopwood Middle School was destroyed by Typhoon Yutu in October 2018. It's still not been rebuilt seven years later. Climate change is a growing threat in the Pacific Ocean. Civil Beat's ongoing series tells the stories of people living on the front lines of climate change.

articles.title: Piece on climate change had glaring holes
articles.author: Sponsored Story
articles.summary: John Crisp writes an essay about climate change. David Herro Hartland criticizes him for ignoring science and engineering. He points out that "renewables" are less efficient at producing energy and affordable electricity than fossil fuels and nuclear and are extremely costly.

articles.title: Ontario thermostat wars heat up. Here's when to flip the switch and how to save
articles.author: Janis Ramsay
articles.summary: Environment and Climate Change Canada confirmed we're moving closer to normal fall weather in Ontario and it's going to get cooler.    .   in many Ontario homes as the temperatures start to dip.  iReport.com: Do you live in Ontario? If so, share this article with others.

articles.title: Total fire ban as millions in firing line for record-breaking heatwave
articles.author: Alexandra Feiam
articles.summary: A total fire ban has been declared across large parts of Australia's east coast. Several records were broken on Monday, with scorching temperatures reported across Queensland, South Australia and NSW. Five heatwave warnings have been issued in Western Australia, Northern Territory, SA, Queensland and NSW, with temperatures expected to peak halfway through the week.

articles.title: Việt Nam backs WMO's early warning initiative: Ambassador
articles.author: Vietnam News
articles.summary: Việt Nam's head of the Permanent Mission to Geneva praised the WMO and UN for their efforts to make early warning a global public good, saving lives and safeguarding development. The climate crisis poses one of the greatest challenges of our time.

articles.title: After getting pounded by storms and offshore hurricanes, what will wounded NC beaches do?
articles.author: Gareth McGrath
articles.summary: This hurricane season has been worse on the Outer Banks than on the N.C. coast. On Topsail Island, chunks of sand that had been pumped onto the beaches have washed away. Wrightsville Beach, New Hanover County, is worried if the town's beach will survive until a scheduled federal nourishment project in 2027. In Surf City, residents are in an uproar over a 30% increase in property taxes this year.

articles.title: **President Trump Expresses Displeasure to Australian Ambassador: "I Don't Like You Either"**
articles.summary: President Trump told Ambassador Sinodinos that he doesn't like him either. The incident occurred during the final months of the Trump administration in late 2020. The relationship between the US and Australia experienced periods of strain during the Trump presidency. The 'America First' policy adopted by the administration occasionally led to friction between the two countries.

articles.title: Glaciers Come and Go, Naturally, and Today's Retreats Are No Evidence of Anything Whatsoever That Man Is Doing.
articles.author: Thomas J Shepstone
articles.summary: Paul Homewood is a former accountant who blogs about climate change. He has written a piece for TCW Defending Freedom on the subject of glaciers and the Little Ice Age. He points out that there is well documented evidence that glaciers in the Alps began retreating long before any increase in greenhouse gases occurred. The same process was taking place around the world, from Alaska to South America and even New Zealand.

articles.title: N.C. counties that busted budgets after Helene still waiting for FEMA to pay them back
articles.author: Brady Dennis
articles.summary: Lynn Austin's community in western North Carolina's Blue Ridge Mountains was devastated by Hurricane Helene. The county government has spent nearly $50 million on cleanup and recovery, but only $4 million from the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which is not very helpful.

articles.title: Record-breaking sea level rise marks fastest in 4000 years, study finds
articles.author: The News Digital
articles.summary: A new study warns of record-breaking sea level rise. Since 1900, global sea levels have surged at an average rate of 1.5 millimetres a year. Anthropogenic activities and climate change are responsible for this rise. China faces a 'double threat' as its largest and economically important cities are highly vulnerable to sinking.

articles.title: 15 Ominous Warnings From The Planet We Keep Ignoring
articles.summary: There's a growing sense that Earth is trying to warn us about climate change. Extreme weather patterns are becoming more unpredictable due to climate change, which is affecting agriculture, water supply, and human health. The frequency and intensity of wildfires have surged. Coral reefs are vanishing at an alarming rate. Global warming is causing sea levels to rise.

articles.title: France raises bird flu alert to ‘high' after more cases reported
articles.author: Al Arabiya English
articles.summary: France has raised its bird flu alert level to 'high' from 'moderate', requiring poultry farms nationwide to keep birds indoors. Two bird flu outbreaks have been detected on poultry farms and three in backyard flocks since mid-October. The change in status will take effect on Wednesday.

articles.title: France Elevates Bird Flu Alert: A Nationwide Poultry Lockdown
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: France has raised its alert level from 'moderate' to 'high' due to rising cases of bird flu across Europe. Two outbreaks have already been detected on poultry farms, with three more in backyard flocks since October. This year's heightened alert is being enforced earlier than in previous years.

articles.title: France raises bird flu alert level to 'high' after new cases
articles.author: Reuters
articles.summary: France has raised its bird flu alert level to 'high' from 'moderate'. Poultry farms nationwide have to keep birds indoors. Europe faces a seasonal resurgence of the disease. Two bird flu outbreaks have been detected on poultry farms and three in backyard flocks since mid-October. The change in status will take effect on Wednesday.

articles.title: UNDP Calls for Renewed Global Effort to End Poverty and Protect Families
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Today is the International Day for the Eradication of Poverty. 2025 theme is 'Ending social and institutional maltreatment by ensuring respect and effective support for families' UNDP's 2025 Global Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) shows a growing link between climate change and poverty.

articles.title: Alaska fishing community updates through the shutdown
articles.summary: The federal government shutdown has affected Alaska's working waterfronts and fishing communities. It has disrupted scientific operations, delayed critical stock assessments, and created new uncertainties for fishermen, processors, and coastal communities that rely on timely federal action. Rural Alaska communities faced the possibility of losing federally subsidized flights under the Department of Transportation's Essential Air Service program as early as October 12. There are also concerns over the closure of federal subsistence offices, leaving rural residents navigating high costs and salmon shortages without direct administrative support.

articles.title: Chennai Drenched: Weather Woes and Agricultural Impact
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Chennai and Tamil Nadu are bracing for heavy downpours. Ramanathapuram and Nagapattinam have reported significant rainfall. Farmers in Tirunelveli districts express concerns over rainfall disrupting paddy harvests. Deputy Chief Minister Udhayanidhi Stalin oversees projects aimed at improving water flow during monsoons.

articles.title: Spring Birds Flock to Belmont Lagoon for Annual Count
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Belmont Lagoon in the Hunter Region is a popular destination for birdwatchers. There are at least 130 native and migratory species using the lagoon. Last year's Aussie Bird Count saw more than 57,000 participants count 4.1 million birds nationwide.

articles.title: October heat records broken across Australia as Sydney braces for temperatures way above the norm
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Birdsville sets new high as BoM forecasts more record hot weather. There are heatwave warnings in place in some states, including some parts of Australia.   For all the latest news, follow our Australia news live blog and get our breaking news email and daily news podcast.

articles.title: Kuruvai crops for harvest affected by rain in Thanjavur
articles.author: NT Bureau
articles.summary: Heavy and continuous rainfall has affected Kuruvai paddy crops in Thanjavur district. About 1,500 acres of fields are waterlogged with crops submerged in standing water due to the ongoing rain. Many farmers have postponed harvests, worsening the loss. The farming community is urging the government to provide relief compensation for the affected crops.

articles.title: Almond-sized crab and tiny lantern shark discovered in Australia
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: Australia is one of the world's biggest biodiversity hotspots. There are more than a million different species living in the country.    .      "Biodiversity hotspot" is home to more than one million species of animals.

articles.title: After the blaze: assessment reveals how Windang Island will recover from fire damage
articles.author: Cookie Pnigdbxqzpgpjmu
articles.summary: An ecological assessment has been conducted of Windang Island after a bushfire scorched around 75 per cent of the land on Sunday. Shellharbour Council's biodiversity and environmental planning team visited the island to assess the damage on Tuesday, October 21. The assessment identified priority areas for weed control in the remaining vegetation to assist natural regeneration as the island recovers from the fire. The island will continue to be monitored during the coming months as the natural environment recovers. The mercury is set to soar to 37 degrees in the Illawarra on Wednesday, October 22, with an extreme fire danger declared and a total fire ban in place for 24 hours.

articles.title: October heat records broken across Australia as Sydney braces for temperatures ‘way above the norm'
articles.author: AOL
articles.summary: October heat records have been broken in several states this week. Authorities in New South Wales are preparing for high temperatures to hit Sydney and the east coast of Australia. The Queensland outback town of Birdsville broke the October heat record this week, which is also expected to be broken in Sydney.

articles.title: Activism has damaged the climate science debate
articles.summary: Green activists accuse the Trump administration of politicization of climate science. Bjorn Lomborg is president of the Copenhagen Consensus and author of 'False Alarm' and 'Best Things First'. He argues that science should not be a partisan game and it's wrong to call out partisanship from just one direction.

articles.title: October heat records broken across Australia as Sydney braces for temperatures ‘way above the norm'
articles.author: Petra Stock
articles.summary: Birdsville in Queensland broke a new October record of 46.1C on Tuesday. The Bureau of Meteorology forecast a Wednesday high of 38C for the Sydney CBD. The October record is 38.2C, set in 2004 at Observatory Hill. There are heatwave warnings in place for parts of WA, the Northern Territory, northern SA, Queensland and NSW. A total fire ban has been declared in the following council areas: greater Sydney, greater Hunter, Illawarra and Shoalhaven.

articles.title: The migrating geese spectacle at Martin Mere Wetland Centre
articles.author: Roger Johnson
articles.summary: Thousands of pink-footed geese have been arriving in the north-west of England on their annual migration from Iceland to the UK. They stop off at Martin Mere Wetland Centre in Burscough, Lancashire to refuel. The centre caters for all ages all year round but it is open free of charge from 17:00-19:00 on Wednesdays and Saturdays until the end of October.

articles.title: Labour's alarmed by the Green surge? So am I.
articles.author: City A.M
articles.summary: Labour's alarmed by the rise of the Greens and is concerned by the fact that Keir Starmer has been too busy fighting Nigel Farage on the right to notice the Greens' rise on the left, as he did with Nigel Farage.   .

articles.title: Record heat, thunderstorms and extreme fire danger coming for Sydney
articles.author: Angus Dalton
articles.summary: A hot mass of air that built up over the Pilbara and smashed temperature records in the outback will hit Sydney on Wednesday, unleashing a scorching day that comes with high winds, extreme fire danger, risk of thunderstorm and severe heatwave warning for parts of NSW. October temperatures were broken on Monday in the inland NSW towns of Tibooburra, which hit 42.6 degrees, and Cobar which hit 40.1 degrees. Similar temperatures for central NSW were forecast for Tuesday before the heat reaches the coast.

articles.title: Gujarat announces Rs 947 cr relief package for monsoon-hit farmers
articles.author: The Hans India
articles.summary: Gujarat government has announced a relief package totalling Rs 947 crore for farmers affected by heavy monsoon rains in August and September 2025. The relief comprises Rs 563 crore under the State Disaster Response Fund (SDRF) and an additional Rs 384 crore from the state budget. The assistance will be extended to farmers across 18 talukas in five districts: Junagadh, Panchmahal, Kutch, Patan and Vav-Tharad.

articles.title: Intense Heat, Fire Danger in Severe Weather Alert
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Incredible temperatures across central Australia will push all-time records. Extremely warm conditions through North Queensland, the Northern Territory, and Northern WA will persist for the rest of this week, into the weekend, and even into next week. Extreme heat can bring a number of different impacts, including increased risk of bushfire-hot weather and dry weather.

articles.title: Aussie town to hit record-breaking 46C today in severe heatwave - as millions are warned to brace for more pain
articles.author: KYLIE STEVENS
articles.summary: Birdsville, in Queensland, is forecast to reach 46C on Tuesday, beating the previous 41.5C record. On Monday, Ballera recorded 44.2C, its hottest October day since 1998, while Thargomindah hit 43.1C. Moomba Airport and Oodnadatta, in South Australia's north, smashed heat records on Monday. It will be the hottest October week in nearly two decades in many outback regions of Australia. Sydney will experience its hottest day so far this spring on Wednesday. Severe weather warning for powerful winds has been issued for southern NSW on Wednesday, with rain, storms and cooler temperatures forecast for capital cities Melbourne

articles.title: Record heat looms and total fire ban triggered as parts of Australia swelter through soaring temperatures
articles.author: Conor Breslin
articles.summary: Temperatures will soar into the 40s in parts of New South Wales and Queensland tomorrow. Firefighters are on high alert as a total fire ban has been declared for vast parts of NSW. The combination of hot, dry and gusty weather is creating 'very high to extreme' fire danger across inland and coastal areas. Employers are being reminded to protect outdoor workers.

articles.title: Wales risks being 'dangerously exposed' to floods, heatwaves and erosion without action
articles.author: David Powell
articles.summary: Researchers visited vulnerable Fairbourne in Gwynedd and warned of 'ageing infrastructure' and 'inconsistent planning' across the whole country. The National Infrastructure Commission for Wales (NICW) found that without urgent action, Wales risks being left exposed to more devastating floods, record-breaking heatwaves and coastal erosion in decades to come.

articles.title: Aussie Bird Count begins
articles.summary: The Aussie Bird Count starts on Monday 20 October and runs until Sunday 26 October. BirdLife Australia invites people of all ages to take just 20 minutes out of their day to spot, identify, and count the birds around them. Last year, more than 57,000 participants submitted nearly 130,000 checklists and logged more than 4.1 million birds across the country.

articles.title: Cyclist puts body on the line to understand the science of magpie swooping
articles.author: Emma Horn
articles.summary: The arrival of springtime is enough to strike fear into the heart and soul of every Aussie, because it's the season when magpies choose violence.    .      in Australia, magpie are dangerous birds.  in the U.S.

articles.title: Scientists issue warning that ancient US feature could completely vanish: 'We'll be the first to see'
articles.author: Matthew Swigonski
articles.summary: Scientists warn that mountain glaciers in California's Sierra Nevada mountains could disappear completely by 2100 due to climate change. The scientists studied rocks recently uncovered by melting ice and measured carbon and beryllium levels that build up when rock is exposed to the atmosphere. Two of California's largest Sierra Nevada glaciers have been continuously covered by ice over the last 11,700 years.

articles.title: Carbon dioxide soared to new high in 2024
articles.author: GILBERT KOECH
articles.summary: Carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere soared to a record new high in 2024. Global average concentration of CO2 increased by 3.5 ppm from 2023 to 2024, the largest increase since modern measurements started in 1957. Methane and nitrous oxide have also risen to record levels. WMO released the annual greenhouse gas bulletin to provide authoritative scientific information for UN Climate Change conference in November.

articles.title: Arctic Climate Shifts: Extreme Weather Unfolds
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: The Arctic is undergoing a remarkable transformation influenced by a myriad of weather and climate extremes. The frequency and intensity of rare climate events in this region has markedly escalated after the year 2000. The Arctic serves as a bellwether for understanding the repercussions of unchecked greenhouse gas emissions. Under a high emission scenario, the probabilities of extreme events will rise at alarming magnitudes.

articles.title: Scientists issue warning after discovering 'enormous' natural phenomenon: 'This is the main cause for the acceleration'
articles.author: Robert Crow
articles.summary: Glaciers in Switzerland have lost 3% of their volume this year. This year's ice loss is the fourth-largest on record, trailing only 2022, 2023, and 2003. Glaciers in the U.S. and Canada have lost nearly 12% of volume since 2020.

articles.title: Earth Has Crossed Its First Climate Tipping Point: Urgent Actions Needed at COP30
articles.author: The Citizen
articles.summary: WWF and other organizations have released a report on tipping points in the Earth's system. It warns about the imminent loss of tropical coral reefs. It also highlights the irreversible melting of polar ice caps, the critical degradation of the Amazon rainforest, and the collapse of ocean currents that regulate global climate. The COP30 on climate change is taking place in Brazil in 2025.

articles.title: Rising Seas, Sinking Cities: Coastal Crisis in China
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Since 1900, global sea levels have risen by 1.5 millimeters per year. Thermal expansion and melting glaciers are driving sea level rise. China's coastal cities are especially at risk because they are built on land prone to subsidence. Many major cities, such as New York, Jakarta and Manila are also built on deltas.

articles.title: Rain causes wildfires – the climate change gospel according to the Met Office
articles.author: Paul Homewood
articles.summary: Paul HOMEWOOD says the Met Office is no longer a serious scientific organisation but a political pressure group. The latest State of Wildfires report is full of contradictions and provides no data to back up their claims that wildfires are more frequent and intense. The report itself admits that last year's fire season was the 8th lowest since 2002.

articles.title: KOPRI finds terrain and ocean shape glacier retreat speed in Svalbard
articles.author: Park Su-Hyeon
articles.summary: Korea Polar Research Institute (KOPRI) analyzed glacier changes in the Arctic Svalbard region over the past 15,000 years and identified the terrain and ocean factors that control glacier retreat. Breakwater-like terrain in the Bellsund area acted as a buffer that slowed rapid glacier retreat during past warm periods.

articles.title: Over 300,000 migratory birds expected to flock to China's Guangdong
articles.summary: More than 300,000 migratory birds are expected to arrive in Guangdong province during the autumn and winter migration peak. GuangDong is a key stopover on the East Asian-Australasian Flyway. Guangdongs coastline is 4,114 km long.

articles.title: The migrating geese spectacle at region's wetlands
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: Large numbers of pink-footed geese have arrived in the North West as part of their annual migration as they are on their way to the South West.    .      in the north west of England and Scotland are seeing large numbers of them.

articles.title: 'It's disgusting': Hunters, wildlife groups react to dumping of migratory birds in Sask.
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: The bodies of 142 snow geese were found south of Saskatoon near Patience Lake last week. Conservation officers are asking for the public's help to identify the perpetrators. The birds were migratory and the major of them were geese, which is a concern for conservation officers.

articles.title: GBCA's Jorge Chapa appointed to global sustainability leadership role (Green Building Council of Australia)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Jorge Chapa has been appointed as the Chief Impact Officer of the Green Building Council of Australia's (GBCA) Global Sustainability Leadership Position until 21 October 2025. He will be responsible for the organisation's global sustainability and sustainability initiatives.

articles.title: Reliable Roof Replacement Services in Jennings, Louisiana: How a Local Roof Replacement Company Protects Homes ...
articles.author: Get News
articles.summary: Daigle Roofing and Construction in Jennings, Louisiana offers roof replacement services. Weather plays a major role in the health and longevity of every roof.       in humid summers, strong winds, and heavy rainstorms, even the best-built roofs eventually wear down.

articles.title: Over 300,000 migratory birds expected to flock to China's Guangdong
articles.author: China Daily
articles.summary: More than 300,000 migratory birds are expected to arrive in Guangdong province during the autumn and winter migration peak. The birds are set to arrive during the fall and winter migratory season. The province is bracing for a significant influx of birds.

articles.title: Australia sees worst recorded flu season in 2025
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: Australia has recorded its worst flu season on record with more than 410,000 laboratory-confirmed cases reported so far in 2025. The tally has surpassed last year's record of 365,000 cases, according to the Royal Australian College of General. The college urges vaccination rates to reverse the trend.

articles.title: Sugar industry body seeks clarity on export policy and EBP roadmap
articles.author: Business Line
articles.summary: ISMA warns of potential economic fallout for sugarcane farmers and the sugar industry as a result of the climate change.      Â  ii   I   i   II   2   3   4

articles.title: Record-breaking CO₂ rise shows the Amazon is faltering — yet the satellite that spotted this ...
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: Asteroid carbon dioxide (CO₂) rose faster in 2024 than in any year since records began. The Amazon rainforest, which has long been a huge absorber of carbon, is struggling to keep up with the rising CO2 levels.

articles.title: New Zealand man describes how he survived face-off with black bear in Japan
articles.author: The Independent
articles.summary: Some experts believe climate change and human activity are to blame for global warming. Others believe it's not so simple as that, as some scientists have suggested.   Â   for different reasons. For more information, go to: http://www.cnn.com/2013/09/20/science/climate-change-and-human-cavernormontane/

articles.title: Sea levels are rising faster than in 4,000 years: Hidden threats to cities, causes and impacts
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Global sea levels are rising faster than at any point in the last 4,000 years. This unprecedented increase is driven by human-induced climate change and natural processes, including thermal expansion, where warming oceans expand, and the accelerated melting of glaciers. It presents an urgent challenge for communities worldwide.

articles.title: Climate change series continues
articles.author: Independent Record
articles.summary: The series "Climate Change: Let's Talk About It" continues at 6:45 p.m. Oct. 27 at the Lewis & Clark Library, 120 S. Last Chance Gulch, at Lewis and Clark Library. For more information, go to: http://www.lwlc.org/.

articles.title: ‘Finance must flow now', says UN climate chief as COP30 nears
articles.author: United Nations
articles.summary: Simon Stiell has urged countries to deliver a rapid surge in climate finance ahead of COP30. Developed nations remain short of resources needed to withstand worsening storms, floods and droughts, according to Stiella. UN Climate Change Chief urges countries to do more.

articles.title: Desertification threatens Iraq's ancient heartland and heritage
articles.author: The New Arab
articles.summary: Iraq is losing its fertile lands to desertification due to climate change, upstream dams and poor water management. Agriculture Minister Abbas Jabr warns that desertification isn't limited to Iraq and needs urgent action if Iraq is to avoid further devastation from climate change and upstream dams.

articles.title: Expert warns Manchester could become 'unliveable' due to global climate change
articles.author: Manchester Evening News
articles.summary: An expert has warned certain UK towns and cities could become uninhabitable due to climate change. There are concerns over the long-term impact of climate change on UK cities and towns due to rising temperatures.       .   in the UK.

articles.title: La Niña is officially here: What you need to know for the winter months ahead
articles.author: NBC Bay Area
articles.summary: La Niña is underway and global temperatures are rising. There is an increased risk of wildfires and severe storms across the country. La Niña conditions are likely to continue through February 2026. Climate change might make the Pacific Northwest a little bit wetter.

articles.title: Record-breaking sea level rise marks fastest in 4000 years, study finds
articles.author: The News International
articles.summary: Record-breaking sea level rise marks fastest in 4000 years, study finds. Anthropogenic activities and climate change are responsible for the rise, according to the study. The study highlights the pressing need for action on both local and global level.

articles.title: 9 additional N.S. communities taking part in climate change program
articles.author: CTV
articles.summary: Nine additional communities in Nova Scotia have been added to a provincial climate change program, which is aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions in the province.       .   in the Province of Nova Scotia.  In the province, there are nine communities added to the program.
